text:
I’m currently studying and designing tools for web scraping/automation. You can see a demo of a tool I made that lets users record their actions on a web page to generate a draft automation script: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z2v8mo-xw3o>. And a short talk about our work: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IyV_xH_kIBQ&list=PLkTCpJUe8hMwLV4miGQbqiqpAYXy4XfN-&index=4>

We’ve recently built a new tool that captures and embeds website UI state within an IDE, provides feedback on CSS selector validity, and more, and I’m looking for JavaScript programmers to participate in a 90 minute user study to test it out. We’ll compensate you with an Amazon gift card of $25 USD (or equivalent currency). Prior experience with web scraping or test automation (e.g., Selenium, Puppeteer, Cypress) is welcome but not necessary! If interested, please fill out this form and I will get in touch with you:
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdwVmGC6SQj7sUHlphmsKVb7rvyn0zZvX-oMNj_0g5xI0qIJA/viewform>

text: this looks great! I’ve signed up! are you also interested in recording-generated selectors a la <https://selectorgadget.com/|selector gadget>? or are you primarily focused on helping people code the selectors themselves?

elements.text: this looks great! I’ve signed up! are you also interested in recording-generated selectors a la
? or are you primarily focused on helping people code the selectors themselves?

text: This is really cool, thanks for sharing! Yeah I had an idea similar to this, where the user provides hints as to why they’re selecting a particular element on the page (e.g., because it’s the first in the list, because it’s orange, because it has xyz text), but haven’t gotten to work on it yet. My current tool is more about providing extra context in the development environment to help people write the code/selectors themselves.
